title: Prime Divisors of Binomial Coefficients
description: For n^ε < k ≤ n^{1-ε}, is ω(C(n,k)) = (1+o(1))·k·Σ_{k<p<n} 1/p? Trivial lower bound: log C(n,k)/log n, tight when k > n^{1-o(1)}.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős asked about the precise count of distinct prime divisors of binomial coefficients C(n,k) in the range n^ε < k ≤ n^{1-ε}. A trivial lower bound is log C(n,k)/log n, which is tight near k = n. The conjecture gives an asymptotic formula involving the prime reciprocal sum.
overview.proofStrategy: We define omega as the prime factors count, primeSumInRange for the prime reciprocal sum, and state the main conjecture as an asymptotic equality. The trivial lower bound and its tightness for k near n are axioms. Basic properties of omega are proved.
keyInsights: ω(C(n,k)) counts distinct prime factors of C(n,k)
The prime reciprocal sum Σ 1/p over (k,n) governs the asymptotic formula
The trivial bound log C(n,k)/log n is tight only when k is near n
The conjecture may extend to k ≥ (log n)^c

sections.title: Prime Divisor Count
sections.summary: Defines omega (distinct prime factors) and primeSumInRange (prime reciprocal sum).

sections.title: Main Conjecture
sections.summary: States ErdosProblem685: ω(C(n,k)) ~ k · Σ 1/p for n^ε < k ≤ n^{1-ε}.

sections.title: Trivial Lower Bound
sections.summary: Trivial bound ω(C(n,k)) ≥ log C(n,k)/log n and tightness for k near n.

sections.title: Basic Properties
sections.summary: Proves omega_one, omega_choose_zero, omega_choose_one. States omega_eq_zero_iff.

conclusion.summary: The formalization captures Erdős Problem 685 on distinct prime divisors of binomial coefficients, the trivial lower bound, and its tightness. 0 sorries.
conclusion.implications: Resolution would quantify the prime factor structure of binomial coefficients across the full range of k.
openQuestions: Is ω(C(n,k)) = (1+o(1))·k·Σ 1/p for n^ε < k ≤ n^{1-ε}?
Does the asymptotic hold for k ≥ (log n)^c?
What is the error term in the asymptotic formula?
